rxJaC0c4wVmxXNJ4B_UGcg.text: Oh how I long to board a plane just to taste this again!! My bf and I walked past this place our first night in Edinburgh but it was closed. For the next three days we kept stopping by after closing =(  Finally on our last day we made it. It seems they prepare one pig and when it's gone it's gone. And by that I mean there is a cooked pig in the window. Some are turned off by this sight. Do not be frightened by the pig he can't hurt you.   We each had a sandwich with haggis and apple spread. Couldn't have asked for a better meal. Don't let the name or the ingredients give you the wrong idea, haggis is delicious! How I wish we had been able to eat here everyday.

_nQbpXuwzzoLgoJzuT1Q1g.text: I would rate this place 10 stars if I could! If you do one thing, and one thing only, do it well. This place does hog sandwiches like no one else. One must get a cracklin to top off a divine sandwich!

L3jWAwg-Dw5toIupqkIMXQ.text: Hog roasts always make me think of weekend food markets and first time seeing a shop dedicated to this goodness.  We were up in Edinburgh for the fringe festival and there are so many choices for fast and on the go food to maximise your time at shows and this is definitely the place to hit up.  My Yelp app is definitely my fave travel companion!    My bf and I decided to share the larger sandwich on a white bun with stuffing and mild chili sauce.  It was oinktastic!  It would be dangerous if there was a place like this in London 'cuz I would probably go there weekly.  I'll definitely be back when I am next in Edinburgh.

yCk2W50BLaMrhK23AhAzHQ.text: My absolute favourite eating spot and the best pulled pork sandwich in the world! yes I said it, in the world! Each day they cook a pig, and yep its perched right out the front to see. You get three sizes, depending on your hunger, starting 2.95 to 4.95 - so price is incredible for what you get! The bun - yep, then either haggis (come on you're in scotland!) or sage stuffing then the sauce apple or a chilli sauce then the pulled pork and ask for the crackling - OMG yum. Seriously was in edinburgh for 6 days, almost ate one of these a day! so good, good value. If you're lucky will get a seat, but generally its eat on the go or pray its not raining (unlikely, you are in scotland) and you can head ot the grassmarket and sit and eat outside. Overall, this is a must stop when in edinburgh!

qBHDvvllM3Km0yAINCc9ww.text: Oinktastic.  This is some seriously fucking tasty pulled pork. The roasted pig in the front window is no gimmick - that's the actual porker they started roasting that morning - and when it's consumed that's it for the day. That's BBQ at it's purest!  The portions are ample, but unless you're not very hungry I'd still recommend ordering at least the "Oink" size. The "Piglet", while adorable, really isn't enough meat for any self-respecting carnivore.  I tried the brown roll, sage and onion stuffing and chili relish on my first try, and I have to say it was heaven. My next visit will probably involve haggis and some crackling, so I'll report back then.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Storefront
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Menu + prices
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. A tasty accompaniment to the pork

NBto_JS6CFr6tb3AM4r4gw.text: Definitely the place to go for a quick delicious lunch whilst roaming around Edinburgh.  Super tasting pork roll which was pipping hot on a fresh roll.  I popped in for lunch when I was exploring the grassmarket with a friend.  Would definitely go again!

ldhV2Hxdr80nLGVW0Oncfw.text: What's better than roasted hog on a big wholemeal role with apple sauce? Nothing. 5 stars!

Ni0VMptSB9W6874K1L4Luw.text: Good value, tasty pork. Would have liked to have been offered crackling as we thought the rolls came with it and it wasn't until we got the rolls back to our hotel that we realised it didn't come with it. Apple sauce isn't very sweet so I'd ask for extra next time.

rmYSFcKP_U5Ii8S-OCmOYw.text: Oh, Oink. Sweet, sweet Oink. This tiny place is nestled amongst the various shops and boutiques of Victoria Street. It can get hot and crowded inside, with only one table for dining-in, but the service is so quick and efficient that you can be in and out with a piping hot sandwich in just a few minutes. Make sure to bring cash, since they don't accept credit cards.  They sell two things: pork sandwiches and drinks. But let me tell you, these are no ordinary sandwiches. Every day they serve their pulled meat from one pig, and one pig only. You can see it sitting there through the window, head and all. It's pretty unique, and you know it's incredibly fresh.  There are three sizes: Piglet, Oink, and Grunter. The Oink is probably the best deal, 3.60 for 160g of meat, though the Piglet is ideal for a tasty snack. I saw someone order the Grunter, and though it looked way too huge for me, it looks like it suits a big appetite perfectly. Each one comes overflowing with juicy pork meat. You can choose your roll, toppings, and sauce as well. Grab an Irn-Bru to go, and you're all set. I've had an Oink with BBQ sauce on a white roll and loved it so much I stopped by for another with apple. Both were outstandingly delicious.  If in Edinburgh, make sure to visit Oink. It usually closes quite early in the afternoon, when the meat runs out, so stop in before it's all gone!

yzvTg8aKDFRwsIiyuHMHLA.text: Oink is just the best. Like, really. Just...just go and eat here. Don't give me your excuses that you're too busy or you're strapped for cash, it's a fiver and you're never too busy for this sort of food. Never.   Oink is a small takeaway joint on the Grassmarket that sells, you may have guessed it, pork. A whole lot of pulled pork. On a roll. Once you go on, there's 3 steps to ordering. Choose your size, Piglet (small), Oink (medium) or Grunter (large). You then choose your filling on the white or brown roll from sage & onion and haggis, and finally choose your sauce, where you can choose from BBQ, chilli cheese or apple. And you can also top it with crispy crackling if you want. Doesn't that sound heavenly? It is.   Today I went for a Grunter with sage and onion and chilli cheese sauce. Ugh, absolutely to die for. I didn't actually notice at the time you could order crackling on it, only through reading other reviews, which I'm slightly saddened by as I love crackling. Oh well, just another reason to be heading back here soon! At only 4.60 for their most expensive option, how could you ever say no?

Mbc7dcy5lzg-4i0q36ygeQ.text: This place represents all what's good in life. I would consider visiting Edinburgh again just for another Grunter with chilli cheese.

OVMxF-k791A_05yRtqxh1Q.text: Fantastic pork sandwiches!!! They sold out the day before so we made sure we were early the next day. Worth going back for!  Make sure to get some cracklings.

uXsob35EHETC0XX6ivXszw.text: Convenient and small looking place for a quick bite. Come in hungry and leave satisfied. Great place for meat lovers. Highly recommended if your walking around Edinburg castle.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Gruntter sand. (Medium)

q5cl-YlgkPZwtQux7jfE6A.text: I'm not normally a fan of pork, given the choice in a restaurant I'll usually go for another meat first but this is deliciously different.  Oink is different, it's a tiny little cafe on Victoria Street, surrounded by (mostly) high quality shops and restaurants.  They sell one thing :  Hog Roast rolls.  Take one pig, roast it, stick it in the window (head and all), keep selling it on rolls until the little piggy is gone and then close the shop.  Pulled roast hog served on a brown or white roll in small, medium or large sizes, with a choice of Haggis, Sage & Onion stuffing, apple sauce or chilli sauce (all for under 5).  If you get there early enough there might be crackling still available too, if you get there too late they could be closed.  They also sell tea, coffee, hot chocolate & cold drinks and occasionally soup.  Sounds simple and it is, but it is gorgeous! You'll be licking your fingers and mopping the juice off your chin by the end, if you're anything like me, it can get a little messy as the juices turn the roll soggy :-) . I personally go for the Haggis & chilli with crackling if available.  The cafe itself is small and fairly basic, I normally take mine (wrapped in tinfoil) down to the Grassmarket and stuff my face on a bench.  They also have an outdoor catering van which you'll find at the Edinburgh Farmers Market every Saturday morning on Castle Terrace, which serves exactly the same thing. A great option for brunch while you do some shopping.

9PJFpPu77aqKfP0i--6wrQ.text: I came here around 4:30pm and they were already cleaning up as they were almost sold out (I was second to last person served) and ordered the Piglet with haggis and apple sauce (I was told this is the more traditional way to eat it). The pork was juicy and melted in your mouth and the haggis was delicious. The combination with apple sauce was surprisingly good. I would definitely recommend to anyone in the area to stop by and grab a bite.

peWzZqF4I51br9wUrRuEjg.text: NOM! NOM! NOM!  First place we made a beeline for after landing in Edinburgh. The pork is delish and made even better with some haggis and chili relish. MAKE SURE you get a piece of the CRACKLIN' to top off the sandwich-- crunchy and porka'licious!   No one talks about the roll but bad bread can ruin a good sandwich. The bread they use at Oink is the perfect juice soaking fluffy goodness a pig could meet. (hey, I wasn't talking about me!)  BTW, seating is quite limited. I recommend finding somewhere to sit either inside or down the street before eating lest you might lose bits of glorious meat down your shirt and that would be a shame.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

RACJMcqZ563ncWaxXPJc5A.text: Please come here. Drop whatever you're doing, bring cash (it's all they take), and come with an empty stomach. The pork rolls here will make you weep with joy and the rest of your day will pale in comparison to the porky perfection.   Aside from cash only, just know that it gets a little busy at Oink and there's only a counter and one table. But it's totally worth doing takeaway.

wOhQIi9fe04zAJhtrcUCPQ.text: Delicious hog roast, well worth the money. You get a choice of roll, stuffing and sauce - it is absolutely delicious for a quick lunch! Best to take away as there is not much seating and it is normally fairly busy!!

HWK0mtQVIMDLQ0M0lo90PA.text: Woooo Pig Soooieeee!!! If you don't know what this means: it's calling the hogs from the University of Arkansas USA.  This place is a gem! Best take away food we had in Edinburgh. All they serve is pig so veggies beware! The roast pork sandwich was exactly what I needed after having a whisky drinking binge the night before. To top it off, you can request a crackling in your sandwich for that special touch. Condiments included onion spread, bbq sauce, spicy cheese, haggis spread and chili sauce. There were probably others I forgot. Sandwiches came in three sizes: wee, medium, large. Freaking delicious! Going back today!

VmcOJMB8kKbwepPyLz4meA.text: Got the bbq on white bread. Very good moist bbq pork and delicious. Staff was friendly and fast. Would recommend to everyone. Wish there was more seating but there is a beautiful public area just down the hill so no big deal. Thinking about the sandwich is making me hungry :)

y0Xd25yArUdXFtVFyz5g9Q.text: The BEST deal in town. One medium sandwich will keep you full the whole day!! Delicious. Full stop.

hFtQ7eB8-iFBYHXPTnGQ8A.text: Great stop for a early lunch. I say early lunch as it can sell out quickly in high traffic areas. Delicious grub for sure. Can't beat the haggis spread with the BBQ sauce great combination! Go there! You won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

PTe25iguSconjaDvnWoXPA.text: This is the first meal I ate in Edinburgh. Fat and lean meat is in a balance I like, just like the ROUJIAMO I ate in China except the sauce.  PS: The price has rised, no more 2.60 pounds now.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. not bad

ChgcOCbpFaI4ZUvUGuLwBw.text: What drew me into Oink? The full roasted pig sitting in the window display! Go in, pick the size of your sandwich (the "oink" medium size was a perfect snack/small meal portion), pick your bread, your stuffing flavor (I went with sage and onion), and your sauce (spicy chili cheese). The meat is super flavorful and juicy. The amount of sauce was minimal and not spicy at all, and I think having the bread toasted would've made it perfect. But I was really happy with my meal, and the worker even gave us a few pieces of cracklin to try out (salty and delicious)! If you're tired of pub grub, give Oink a try!

AU0h3h1IoZR_DFywgqiqjA.text: Dropped in to grab a nice warm cup of tea.  Nice little shop.  Enjoyed our short time at Oink.

chJ89pf6og6EfwKi5Bc3yg.text: No stars (but was forced to select one to post).  My daughter was sick after eating there.

I0AisUgg7VXm99UyBoW37g.text: Great place to drop in for a pulled pork sandwich.  Try it with the sweet chili sauce!

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Legit pulled pork

2uEYAoxcyjg5js3_aIprUg.text: Small venue made all the better by making you want to be included. Exciting when the seat opens and then you realize that with a little patience seats will open. Wait for it. The Pork is so tender with a light spread of haggis   If you think you don't like haggis , well you are wrong. This is a treat. And so worth the hike and the 5 minute wait that was only 2 minutes.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

f8r20cupyuRPt0vXJ8B1bg.text: Honestly don't understand what all the hype is about. We stopped in and tried it out. Not impressed. It was cheap and did fill us up, so that's a good thing! I'm not really sure what it was, maybe our choice of bbq sauce? None of my party of four found the sandwiches to be very good. We all got the exact same thing so who knows if something else would be more to our liking.

_OdYJy61-jkhzqxYtZ8_oQ.text: That's some good pig. Pick your size, bread, topping, and sauce... don't forget to ask for some "cracklin'" if that's your thing. Select a sugary beverage. Delight in pulled porky goodness either on premises or down the street in the glorious Grassmarket Plaza area.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Oink, on Brown bread, sage and onion stuffing, bbq sauce and crackling in front. Tasty!

vg5kWUDmbJGsLTiDBojKyQ.text: Excellently executed local twist on an already delicious pulled pork sandwich.  I had the grunter, the largest of their sandwich offerings, with the haggis stuffing and chili cheese sauce. Soft bread, very moist pork, and a tangy sauce combined in a knock-out flavor experience!

ZYwX5rfaDD2n-cW0kmjl1w.text: Really tasty. Deducting a star because they wouldn't take my cash. They decided not to accept 5 pound notes and charged me to use a card. Pro tip: If you decide not to take cash, don't charge to use a card.

6H69m-ZuY6albzukIGCHVQ.text: They were chopping up a whole pig right in front of me.  Poor lil guy.  Whatever, he tasted deeeelish.

Fcl08-mn6MofhHyRBY3B9g.text: So I walked past, saw the pig in the window, and even though I was actually looking for 'brunch' I couldn't resist. It was a mistake. But a delicious one. One that I'll never regret. For about 4 you can get yourself an amazing pork sandwich, wet with oily drippings of sweet delicious pig fat. Incredible. Sage and onion or haggis are stuffing options, along with you choice of sauce such as apple sauce, mustards, I had chilli cheese. My arteries hardened the minute I walked out of that place, but my mouth is watering just thinking about it, oh my god just go there!! The pork was moist, the sandwich amply packed, the chilli cheese sauce both spicy and cheesy. I'm still drooling.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Pork with haggis and chilli cheese sauce. The photo doesn&#39;t do it justice. The pork is tender and the sandwich is jam packed with meat.

KqVlWWW1YGrEunl9mAQkxA.text: Very close to the Edinburgh castle, ~5mins walk. It was a good value for the price but the meat was kind of bland and more seasoning would really help.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

b6sr549sKFj4dDov6NWdqg.text: OINK!!! I love this pork sandwich so much, I'll be coming back to Edinburgh to taste it again! Especially enjoyed the one with the haggis.

2pihxz5iEF47hJinJxieHQ.text: Great food to go. Filling and cheap. I which they extended a bit their hours as the do during the festival.

bTCYH9gkBIyOQvo86YEMtg.text: HOLY MOLY! Not Kosher but delicious! Amazing shredded pork  what a find when they run out.....they run out  go early  always a line  its worth it

5sN7obFUJsT_VHcFgWMD9w.text: I don't think I've ever seen a menu this simple, but yeah basically it's what you see roasting by the window.  If you're at all squeamish about seeing what meat looks like before it becomes meat, you might not want to pop in for a visit, but otherwise I can't think of many other places that can fill you up with a nice hearty lunch without draining the wallet.  The pulled pork I found to be a bit bland, but maybe that sort of plain-ness is normal.  It is, however, supplemented by incredibly flavorful fillings and toppings, and the meat is basically just a medium for all that goodness.  Definitely ask for some crackling if you're a fan.

t3MSc8DtIEpMLoRNbKxf6g.text: I came here on a weekday night with a friend, and it was semi-packed. The shop isn't too big so there wasn't much seating, but it's a nice and cozy place. I got a classic white roll with apple sauce, which was recommended to me and I thought was weird upon ordering. But it was delicious! The apple sauce had a nice balance with the meat. There was so much meat in the sandwich though; I wish there were more sauce and more vegetables! The pork was pretty good and flavorful, although I think my sandwich was too big. Towards the end of eating it, I no longer wanted to eat it because there was too much meat! Good place to try out though.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Regular roll with apple sauce! Yum.

qQxFN-uJUXskR92svCgk6Q.text: I had never been here before, but my boyfriend, a tourist to our city, had. So, I set about putting that right.  What can I say that has not been said before, it is truly a wonderful bite to eat, and a querky type of place. I love it.  3 prices, choice of accompanying sauce, and that's it  Just the most delicious pork ever.   They have the whole roast hog in window, and saty open till it's all gone.

v76u9uEroTN1shw-I7LWFg.text: Oink makes me happy.   Its that simple.    I live in Los Angeles and I would be willing to take the 11 hour plane flight for a sandwich at Oink.  Basically what you get is pork.  Slow cooked, displayed for all, sweet juicy cracklin, and some nice local toppings.    If your looking for variety, look somewhere else.  If you want an amazing inexpensive pork sandwich that will knock your socks off, look no further.

iXMRPX2IAV0JFxF40EEb5Q.text: This place is so simple yet very complex. The pig: Raised on their farm where they breed them. They come from a specific gene line that ensures quality (yes not all pigs are the same in taste).  Their oven is custom made and fits up to 20 pigs which are monitored the entire time they're cooked (12 hours).  These guys sling up to 1500 sandwiches a day during busy festivals. They also cater large parties and weddings. BBQ sauce was added a few years ago mostly due to the demands of Uhmerricins. Before then they were so proud of the product they wouldn't allow it.  The guy behind the counter (round salt n peppa head) explained it all to me at the end of a long day. His buddy (ginger) was nice and helpful as well. True gentlemen. The pork was amazing. THE BEST I have EVER HAD. I couldn't decide between the options so I had half haggis stuffing and half onion stuffing with half tomato relish and half applesauce on mine. I left uber excited.

rSHwRZ5LbV1GgHxtFSWBHg.text: Small but fantastic. Wonderful pork sandwich. The stuffing gives it a great Thanksgiving flavor.

2k_QRpD3sv8LStb0FXsj8Q.text: Pork sandwich: small, medium, or large - all else are details. Had mine with sage dressing and sweet chili sauce with a ginger beer. Tender pork pulled from a whole roasted hog prominently displayed in the front window. Having grown up going to L.A. Chinatown delis with roast pigs and ducks hanging from windows, Oink's display didn't faze me so I went hog wild. Tasty food at reasonable prices in a store with cute pig displays. Another good recommendation from Yelper Jenny L.

7tbBibKF05XrGx4c3F95ig.text: Thee best meal we had during our visit to Scotland. Travellers do not pass this place up. Pig Sandwich with haggis, apple spread and crackling skin was OUTSTANDING. Wish we would of had it sooner instead of our last day there or we would of ate there everyday. Hope to make it back in the future

E2S8cWgNpSS8uwb2Snk8dg.text: On victoria st near the grassmarket - this is the best food plave in that area easily (that ive been to anyway). It's easy to find, just look for the whole cooked pig in the window. The menu is pork rolls in 3 sizes - piglet (for kids), oinker and grunter (the big one). I went for the grunter with haggis and apple sauce and was very satisfied. The other filling options are onion and sage stuffing and chilli sauce which i'll definitely be back for.

WeDZBalSv7aV_Ts_0xJDow.text: Cool concept and nice stuffings and sauces but my pork bun was dry at Oink.  I will give Oink a second try if I ever find myself in Edinburgh again.

ISqPfvTThIbEubR_VkQufw.text: Sensational, delicious, mouth watering, tender, succulent roast pork and crackling in a bread roll. No better 'ready to devour' pork purveyor this side of the Carpathian's I can assure you. The whole roast pig in the window had me drooling before I even went inside, Obelix-style!

oJNcV-RMnZtq1UEkYfTa9A.text: Simplicity at its best- there is just one thing on the menu and its life changing. The beautiful hog sits in the window like the Sirens tempting all who pass by. The pork sandwich comes in three sizes, the largest of which is a deal breaker if you plan on accomplishing anything with the rest of your day. The meat is extremely tender and delicious. Without a doubt Oink is an Edinburgh must. To top everything off, Oink is located near the Grassmarket, the tightest place in the city.

yRgWk8vFoDcoJjhYo-sd3Q.text: Simply and utterly fabulous -- the best pork I've had, ever, anywhere, anytime.  Among the best meat I ever had.    Unlike factory raised pork, this isn't your "other white meat."  Dark, succulent and deliciously fatty.  I keep my order simple -- no bread, no sauce and no sides, just meat and cracklin.  Actually tried some haggis once, which is offered as a side, on one visit.  The haggis was fine even though it wasn't in the casing, but the pork is sublime.    The staff are friendly and the prices are reasonable.  Keep up the excellent work.  I'll be back the next time I'm in town.

zs-tMoyBqFwCu7V_lKv5hg.text: The price is right and the food is delicious. Tender and juicy pork on soft yummy rolls - how much better can it get?

3N36a9ILQgWFny9eFqTe9w.text: This will be my regular lunch stop in town.  Probably the one place in UK that beats American BBQ joints... yeah, that good.  Maybe because the first time I had it was freezing cold and late afternoon, but the meat was plenty, tender and juicy.  The chili sauce reminds me of St. Louis bbq.  Sorry, vegetarian friends, pig is the only thing on menu here.  Oh, and expect to eat your sammy standing up.

ZOfF93bAdjFmi68wU7BrBA.text: the pork tasted so good with the apple sauce!

ny1kaRTzivabvg46lvvJKQ.text: I didn't even notice the place until I walked by then the smell hit me hard. I had to go in and try one of these sandwiches. It was amazing... melt in your melt and full of flavor. Get extra crackling, I made the mistake the first time and won't again, possibly the best part.  For the quality of food, and flavor I would have expected to pay more money. If your in the area I highly recommend you stop by for a sandwich or a drool...your choice.

M3luvhfYHhqcmjtg14AIjQ.text: What is it about a a dead pig that arouses so much excitement in a person? I lived next to the market where the Oink hog was marched to on a saturday, in the days before their shop opened on Victoria Street, and I would be lying if I said I wasn't captivated by its piggy mystique. Maybe it awakens a hunter gatherer impulse within us - or maybe we have seen too many episodes of Lost - but, for some reason, the sight of an entire dead pig (think apple in the mouth) gives an incredible and inexplicable urge of "I want that inside me".  I'm afraid, however, that the reality is that it tastes OK and not much better than OK. Once you get over the fact that the butcher has just done slightly less work on your lunch and that you are not in fact standing in the wilderness, but on a street which has become reminiscent of a building site, this piggy mystique begins to vanish.  To put this another way, imagine a Yelp friend proclaiming the latest city lunch craze city to be a kebab shop with an entire skinned lamb revolving slowly in front of a small radiator, head, legs and all. You may begin to be willing to reappraise your dining priorities.   In short, it's tasty enough, but lets not go over board here people. How often would you choose a pork sandwich when given a choice? Just imagine they kept the ingredients in the kitchen, like everyone does.

XEby3OtKZE-EyGc_XCxZGQ.text: I love single specialty places. Very simple Full Roasted Hog. Served in 3 sizes with your choice of accompaniments. Arrive early ashes ingle hog served sells thru in a few hours. Ask for the crackling if you arrive early enough.

1PuHdTz4rttOSH7WorSN1Q.text: I LOVE OINK! I had breakfast and lunch here during the festival, the meat is beautiful melt in your mouth and the staff are lovely. The prices are great for central Edinburgh - will always go back here every time I go to Edinburgh

7SBMXHAz7QpXSpjHKvHGxA.text: This is the kind of place that makes you feel like a child standing outside a sweet shop- only instead of a child, you're a 22 year old woman, and instead of a sweet shop it's a shop with the whole roasted carcass of a dead animal in the window. The reaction, however, is the same- glee; pure, unadulterated glee. The first time I walked past this place I quite literally shoved my head against the window and stared at the glistening roast hog for at least 75 seconds. Then I stared at the people who worked there for a little while, in a poor orphan Annie kind of way, in the vain hope that they would throw me some scraps of crackling. Then my friend made me leave. BUT THEN I returned one other day, and realised I'd found my spiritual home. I'm not allowed wheat so asked for just meat and sauce, no roll, and that is what I got- a big pile of juicy meat, some crackling and some delicious sauce. Now my friend got a roll, and it looked pretty good, and she made noises which I don't think anyone has ever been able to extract from her before, so delicious did she find the sweet sweet meaty goodness enveloped inside her bap. All in all, this place is amazing, albeit terrible for my arteries.

bom7uQ8r4N2vaS3tMQKywg.text: Used to be cheap here, but they keep putting up the prices, so it's now almost five quid for what's basically just a hot pork sandwich, and not even a particularly big one at that. Plus if you get a cold one, which is half the price, the woman there gets well moody about it, like she doesn't want to serve it. Used to like it there, but stopped going cos of her, and since I discovered Hula down the road, which is better and cheaper.

aLxhWNuNzLhoI6xo-GAhvQ.text: Orders: OINK   Fee:  3.95   Waiting time: 30s   Taste: I am really to expect this food, cuz it just looks like Chinese marinated meat in baked bun. However, it is not as good as I imagined. The pork is a little dry and stiff that push me to drink more water. Maybe I eat too quickly, my stomach has not comforted.   The food is so enough for lunch. I may try next time.   Wills:

XjfsHBNXhepgvGPwrCtWpw.text: Quick, filling and delicious! It is a small place with a simple menu, but is a very good option for lunch. I recommend haggis and apples with your sandwich.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. You won&#39;t  leave hungry!

fdBhzmCRE8OgglQBlX5UEw.text: Wonderful! I got the small with applesauce on my way to Hollyrood Palace and it was a great walking snack.

Wu6gCKYmrFsOJS59LXGMbQ.text: Loved this place! Quick service, good value, and delicious sandwiches! Ate so quickly, I forgot to take a picture! Wish this chain would come to the US!

WUD0kI4mQiB2ibN2d-vUfw.text: Terrific pork sandwiches. Menu is simple -- pick size (we got pink, which is the medium...though grunter--the large is the same size bread only with more meat), white or brown bread, stuffing, and sauce. We got sage and onion stuffing with apple sauce. A great snack for 5ish pounds. Lines get long around lunch.

7Bh-NSbL_KdWJLtA7RsZXQ.text: Good not great.  Lineup outside the door but moves quickly.  Choice of brown or white bun.  Bun seems like it can be bought from a local supermarket, cold and squishy.  The pulled pork is the star, very moist and has gold flavour.  I chose the onion to go with the pork and the texture was a bit weird.  I am not dying to go back again.

myFEvvi3CybNzmcGnINofg.text: Taste is fine. Always a long queue there. If u here have a try. Good choice for eating and walking~

R2eFoW6PW_DDMONBB8BGUA.text: This place is great! As an American who lives in th south i was a little curious what pulled pork would be like in Scotland... it's not super smoky, but it is melt in your mouth tender! I do wish that they had sides that you can pair with your sandwich... only complaint is that the menu is a little limited.  They do take credit cards! I believe there was an 11lound minimum.

CumUonkd9kbaiZ-wn7H3vA.text: My husband has been looking forward to having a meal here for several months. It was one of the first things he mentioned after we got off the train at Waverly Station, and it kept creeping into conversation as the days in Edinburgh swept on by.  We finally had a chance to give it a try the day before we were set to leave for Prague. We each got the "The Oink" - which is a regular-sized version of the sandwich. I chose to dress my brown roll with sage and onion and the chili relish, while my husband chose the apple sauce and chili relish on a white roll.  They are cash only, and their "dining room" is almost non-existent, so if they're busy, you may have to take your sandwich to go. As it was, the one table by the window was taken, and the one bar area (with four chairs) was also taken. We were just discussing where we could go to eat when the guys at the bar offered us their seats, as they were finishing up.  The sandwich was good, but I wasn't blown away by it. I guess I had built it up in my head so much over the months - we talked about it, we drooled over the pictures - so I was expecting it to knock me on my bum.  It was decent, and it filled me up. Plus, it was by far the cheapest meal we had on the entire trip, so that has to count for something.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Front window
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Oink

pUhvm1Wwfhm9s_qotrpPRA.text: I stumbled on this eatery as I wandered the Royal Mile. It was delicious! I had the oink with sage and onions. My mouth did a happy dance from the first bite to the last. Highly recommend!

J4NiVjFxZzejzpzRf4ATzw.text: It was ok.  The meal deal was good with a drink and chips. I had the regular sized sandwich which was very filling, it just needed more seasoning... I had the apple type of sauce, it was a bit bland. The shop was small and quaint, the staff was very helpful and welcoming. I just wanted more seasoning and flavor. Loved the pig display in the window and its display!

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Pull pork sandwich on wheat bread
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Pig roast display with pulled pork

iRh5-M80RX6ms2oTAFOZMw.text: What can I say.   If you love swine and are in Edinburgh it would be a crime to not go here.  I ate it every day that I was there every time I have been there.  It's that good.  If I could figure out how to import it to NYC there would be a mile long lunch line to get it.  The rolls are delicious.  The pork is so tender it will blow your mind.  The haggis spread is the perfect Scottish touch.   Tip:  Get the medium or large.  Definitely get the haggis spread and the homemade BBQ sauce and don't forget to ask for some cracklings.  After you are done, go right across the street to the Bow Bar and get a pint of local Scottish ale or glass of whisky.    That, my friend, is a perfect day.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

-FY136li_OKQS78svh8Y_A.text: The line for this place is huge! I got in at a good time but it always seems busy. The lady behind the counter was super nice. A sandwich is around 4 and not the most filling. I was still a bit hungry after. I found the sandwich dry and I've definitely had better pork elsewhere. I think maybe with some mayo or something it might've tasted better? Just to dry for my taste. People love it though.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. So dry!

HW8NXS_8uAoW96UALuPjRw.text: Yep. This is it. This is where I want to eat, die, come back and eat again. I love Oink.  They have two locations in Edinburgh, and in the week I was there, I went there twice.  Hog roast/pulled pork the way it should be done. They have the whole hog they roasted and pull from in the window. It's locally sourced from a farm outside of the city, which I am pretty sure belongs to the owners. They know pigs.  I got a Grunter (the largest size), with haggis as a topping (because it was delicious and only the good die young), and tried a few of their creatively made sauces. You can get two smaller sizes, and other toppings are available. They also have sandwiches to go if you are in a hurry. The bread holds, bites, and chews with the best of them, but the highlight is obviously that sweet sweet pig. Here's the kicker: It's super affordable...  Go to it. Seriously. Get up, get a Grunter, waddle off the food baby on the royal mile, then go to the grassmarket and get your second. 5 stars well deserved.

7RuK1sVF1dEbTZCNSsR_jg.text: Delicious! We had the Oink sandwich with the spicy chili cheese sauce and sage and onion stuffing and it was so good. It reminded us of thanksgiving dinner in a yummy way.

nEN3f42h-D2M55C7pyRa9A.text: Traveling from London to Edinburgh to Dublin and no joke... this is the best food I had the entire time and I had some good s**t. Highly recommend the haggis stuffing and the homemade chili jam. You made my trip worthwhile Oink. Damn you smoke a good pig.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

A0fXPJSNrH1tyyaH_GaiRQ.text: Excelent food! Be sure to be early because it runs out of sandwiches very soon. A must in Edinburgh.

URap-4s6xH55FDUWQL99dg.text: Perfect way to warm up!  We visited Edinburgh on one of the coldest days of the year, very windy/rainy/etc.. and found Oink to be our go-to stop for warming up and filling up. The Grunter is not for the faint of heart, but it is wonderfully worth it.  I'd recommend: Grunter with haggis stuffing!

hguDmKVxTHsd98UPaQ3svA.text: There are a few addresses that I couldn't make it during my short trip to Edinburgh, but I'm glad Oink wasn't part of them. It may be True that I insisted to visit this place...  Good for the budget (last day of the trip) and for the palate!! Craving for some now, not sure that I can get some as good as Oink's in Paris...

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Oink Oink

ndZ6sOMN2socvjLi7jC5HQ.text: Here's what you need to know dear reader: of all my dining experiences throughout Scotland, Oink was without a doubt the best. End of story. Star 1: How was the service and atmosphere? Quick and hassle free, Oink is about as straight forward as it comes, which is marvelous considering you really should be out and about enjoying the wonderful city that is Edinburgh. Walk up, order your roll, and walk out with a full meal in under three minutes. Brilliant. Star Granted. Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost? Guys. Just stop. Guys. Seriously. Now hold on just a second. This sandwich: yelp.com/user_local_phot... This beautiful, filling, meaty sandwich. Cost me 3.60. That's it. That's like... less than literally anything in any of the gift shops in Edinburgh. Beautiful. Star Granted. Stars 3 and 4: How was the food? DELICIOUS. First and foremost? The roll. Freshly made. Flaky. Buttery. Warm. Ugh. So good. The pork? Well, the whole damn pig is right there in front of you, so you know it's as fresh as it possibly could be. It tastes exactly like it should, and is only made better by one of the fantastically unique sauces that are made available. This is honestly as good if not better than a lot of the pork barbecue I can get in Dallas. Dual Stars Granted. Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could? Without a second thought. This is as good as it gets. Star Granted.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Oink: £3.60

CESl3AwoBtorhJmnvSxyeQ.text: We were heading to collect our torches for the torch parade - with only minutes left on our parking meter.  We were speed walking up Victoria street and caught a glimpse of Oink.  It was after 3pm. There was a line.  There didn't appear to  be much left.  It only took a second to hatch a brilliant plan:  I would go for the torches while my husband would get in the line a grab a couple of pulled pork rolls.  It wouldn't take any extra time and we could still get back to the car before the hi-vis clad parking attendants pounced.  the outcome???  I grabbed the torches and jogged back to Oink.  Just as I neared Oink I saw them putting a 'Sold Out' sign on the door.  I looked around and couldn't find my other half.  Was he successful?  Did he get some rolls?  Ahh....there he was, coming up the road and what did I see?  2 foil wrapped rolls in his hands.  Success!    We made a bee-line back to the car  where we were able to take a few minutes and tuck into our little parcels of delight.  These really are the best pulled pork rolls I've ever had.  The meat is soooooo tender. It's 'pulled' but not too stringy - there are big, flaky chunks to sink your teeth in.  And the juices are savory, delicate, and compliment the meat perfectly.  You can get bbq sauce on top but I prefer au naturale.  In fact, I don't like it when some places cook the pork in a barbecue sauce - too over powering for me.  A brown roll and a little applesauce were my perfect combination.    Pictures?  Not this time.  They didn't last long enough!  But don't worry - we'll be back!!

DiBkR1r-nd772FPnAOl-Cg.text: Oink if you're hungry! The delicious roast pork is some of the best I've ever had. The bread roll was soft and the savory haggis with chili relish was the perfect spread to compliment the pork. I had the middle-sized Oink roll, which was a good portion for lunch. When the man offers you the crispy crackling, don't turn him down. The crackling (crispy pork skin) was the best part! If you're a hog fan, Oink is a great place to stop by for a bite without hurting your wallet.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Oink
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Pig is delicious
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

T6IkwaPjVAUDGoCpIFwtVA.text: Did someone say Pig? Copious amounts of meat, never leave hungry!

4VdtWdeG5EMBNdHmlwxPrg.text: Delicious!!! We got 2 medium sized sandwiches with 2 drinks for 11!!!! The rolls were meaty and very tasty...give this place a try!!!

RpeyN8nZPXxMHbZL2OwOtw.text: Oink was great.  Nestled between quaint shops up the hill from the grass market, it is the perfect place to get a quick bite for lunch if you are on the go.  Their simple menu lacks variety, but more than makes up for it in quality.  You can make your own sandwich- size, bread, meat/topping, and sauce selections.   I was really hungry after going on a long walking for of Edinburgh, and I needed something quick. Oink was perfect for that. I ordered my sandwich and had it in my hand in less than 5 minutes.  Recommend for lunch in a busy day. You won't regret going to this great sandwich joint

EucYq-p6DlNZ0Us9o2sDjg.text: Great little place.   Perfect for a quick on the move lunch.   The hog was very tasty, generous serving in a white role with haggis and apple sauce, which were very nice with a scottish touch.   The display of the Hog in the window adds to the experience :)   I always get a hog roll from here when ever I pass by, even when I am not hungry.   Enjoy

iSlKhVqZwEztQdIDbnQz5w.text: Walking through the streets of Edinburgh on our way to Holyrood, my new husband and I casually looked through a window to see a fully cooked pig, half of it's body pulled apart into glorious, tender looking pulled pork. Even though we had already eaten (an a stinky lunch at that), who can resist pork that looked as good as that? No one I tell you. No. One.   There are a couple different size options, filling options, and sauce options. We had it twice in our trip and pretty much tried everything. I would suggest getting two small sammies, one with the sage stuffing and one with the haggis stuffing as both are great. There barbecue sauce is pretty darn amazing and the price is totally worth it. For a small place, they sure do a lot of business and that shows how good the food is. Definitely worth it to stop in, especially while wandering around Edinburgh!

H2WvKoopjzlYlCOojB8biw.text: So being an ex veggie I had avoided this place due to the big pig in the window. Even though I am now a meat eater, I still had a twinge of guilt every time I walked past. Today was the day when I told that guilt to just get lost and let me enjoy a delicious roll. I'm so glad I eventually let the meat eating side of me wine. Oink certainly lives up to the hype. I went for the Oink with haggis. I ended up avoiding the relish, as I am a picky one and wasn't sure what to expect from them. The meat itself was just wonderful. There is always a worry that pork will be a quite dry but not with Oink. There is a larger option available but personally 'The Oink' was big enough for me. Go along and let your meat eating side win!

ewyBk05rLxsMtXUB2j9Wew.text: I thought it was just okay, my husband would have probably given 4 stars. I got the oink with onion stuffing with applesauce and I thought it was pretty bland. About half way through I asked for another sauce to spice it up a bit and they said it'd cost an extra 1. I think that's silly because the menu says choose your "relishes" ... Plural.. And wouldn't you want your guests to enjoy their food? Well, in return I'll write this review, so I guess we're even :).  Meh, it was ok, I wouldn't recommend it to others but it was fine.

cg9PRZGK-fYdleU-FmrCBg.text: I popped in here to grab a quick bite and the juicy pulled pork sandwich did not disappoint!   Grunter:  Step 1: White roll  Step 2: Haggis  Step 3: Mild chilli   Quick, affordable, and tasty! Wished I tried the crackling though.

bVpklyMc3DyW1WUKBPGyHw.text: Literally my favorite food joint ever! I stopped by Scotland on a Europe tour and this is by far the best food place I've been to. The sandwiches are delicious, customizable, and cheap! I thought the oink portion was going to be small but they stuff it with a lot of meat so I was full from just one sandwich. I came here constantly during my stay in Edinburgh and I would come back to Scotland just for the sandwiches here!

fcQYrZOOhOTazD0AUxjkbw.text: Definitely a great place to stop in for a unique sandwich when you are near Victoria Street and the Grassmarket. Obviously, I ordered the Grunter - the largest hog roast sandwich offered. The real dilemma came when choosing a base and a sauce. The server recommended the sage and onion layer, so I went with that. I asked that he put the apple and chili sauce in small cups so that I could try the sandwich sauceless, with the sweet apple sauce, and chili sauce.  All three combinations were great. The sandwich was excellent on its own. The apple sauce added an interesting element of sweetness while the chili sauce added an element of tanginess.   The most memorable part of the experience is seeing the hog in the storefront.

HU0CycFtXtkcD5wMZFj3ew.text: With apple sauce and haggis, this was a very good sandwich. I only wish I could have sat somewhere to eat it! I will certainly go back next time I am in town :)

9rtk-KZblClnDj01rzDjUA.text: If you are anywhere near this place.... GO EAT THERE!

tKtW_RlWDMemEc2b1Uh1bw.text: Pretty good but they give you this food on a cheap flimsy morning roll which quickly falls apart in sogginess. Its not exactly cheap either (for local non tourists) which  makes me not want to go back because they are being too greedy for profit.  Either make it cheaper or serve it on decent bread.

MXt9sXCVMGr8IAW6Mg9i5w.text: I looked at my clock and estimated my time of arriving after deliving a cake and thought "oh yes" to myself!    The 16 oz Oink with apple sauce and crackling was more than enough.  Although would of liked a tad bit more apple sauce to balance it out.  The crackling was quite salty for me though.  It's filling so well worth the money for 3.60.  Defo a winter warmer too!  I will be back - mmmm maybe BBQ next time!

Pp-Bh--NT3u_Nba8OIIzXQ.text: Great pork sandwich!  Moist and flavorful. I went for the sage, onion, and apple sauce but would love to go back and try some of the other toppings.

2j3F85gez20tgSqZoWN_Vg.text: As tasty as the piggy looks from the outside, I wasn't too impressed with my oink sandwich. I ordered mine with BBQ sauce and after taking the first bite, I found the meat to be dry. I quickly asked for more sauce. You know it can't be that good if I'm asking for more sauce to make it taste better. In addition to the dryness, the meat was room temperature. I guess this is how they're served, but I would've preferred mine to be hot.   Other than my not so special sandwich, the shop is cute since it's on a lovely street just off The Royal Mile. The workers weren't particularly friendly, but nice enough to serve me my sandwich. Some people love it, I just wasn't a fan...

milB4pvRKEHqOnxIEenuAg.text: Gorgeous, gorgeous, porky goodness on an in!  I had the Oink with Sage & Onion stuffing and apple sauce.  Heaven.  My husband had the Oink with haggis and chili sauce, which was also fab.  We travel from the states to eat here, and dream of it when we're away...

maVaiX7MUMYoDxtShbi2DA.text: This review is specifically for those that (don't shoot me!) simply don't LOVE these type of sandwiches... I think they are OK, but tend to feel a bit let down in most instances.  (To be fair, I think I've ruined my taste buds with hot sauce and chillis over the years.)    I've actually been past a few times and wanted to pop in, but it was always after they had run out... while normally this irritates me, the potential for irregular hours, I get it at this place... as others have mentioned, whole pig in the window is what they do, when it's gone it's gone for the day.  I was really hoping that Oink would change my mind for these type of sandwiches, it looked fantastic, even though I creep myself out thinking "that crispy skin looks tasty", but it is what it is, and I've heard many good things about the place.  I had the medium sized sandwich with haggis and the spicy cheese sauce... while good, and definitely on par with similar places, it still didn't rock my world.  (Trust me, I feel terribly bad about this... I spend time pondering what must be wrong with me... I mean, it looks fantastic, is perfect on paper, and everyone else loves it... so what gives?)  I was really hoping the haggis and spicy cheese sauce would jazz it up, but it still just fell a bit flat for me personally.  All of that said, I can definitely see why people like it and the prices are great for where it is so I feel anything less than four stars would be unfair in this instance... but, if you happen to be the other 1 in 1,000,000 that doesn't love plain(ish) pulled pork sandwiches, then I'm not 100% certain that this place would change your mind.

12lFp2hfwxaAn6nZov03jQ.text: Mehhhh. Overrated. The sandwhich I had lacked flavor and had too much of a mayonnaise like substance on it. It was cheap and ot was just okay. I would recommend eating hear if your drunk and to accompany your sandwich with a beer.

BODTCuJ5jrsbI0ICbbwN8Q.text: Pulled pork sandwich stuffed with haggis.  You want that.  If you're in Edinburgh and only eat one thing, make it that.  Oink does whole hog butchery and just serves from the pig in the window until they run out. You can choose from three sizes (the bun of the adult sizes are the same, they just pile it higher with meat). The medium size is way more than enough.  You also get your choice of sauce. Additional toppings cost extra, but you really don't need any.  Hands down, one of the best sandwiches I've ever had!

Z-gCxXgC3WlfpBuY4p8KTw.text: Oink makes a delicious and surprisingly affordable roast pork sandwich right in the heart of the tourist district of Edinburgh.  I came by early afternoon on a Friday and the small space in Oink was line-out-the-door PACKED. There is a bit of seating but mostly this should be considered sandwiches for take away (unless you are one of the lucky few seaters).  The sandwich came with a choice of sauce and a nice, fresh bun. The pork was good if a TAD on the dry side. Overall very good, especially for the price and location.

O4D-a_yMEh4DZ2alIICSNg.text: Really enjoyed this place.  The staff was very pleasant and helpful.  My wife and I enjoyed our sandwiches and had no trouble finding a place to sit even though it can be quite busy.  The pork was excellent and the haggis was the best I had tasted on our trip around Scotland.  I had the crackling with my sandwich and it was delicious, just like we used to have when we baked a ham in the US.

T9ZWYeCVSUNGPllJw_QzwA.text: Not as amazing as when it used to be on a food truck at the weekend farmers market 10 years ago, but still delicious nonetheless.  It used to be hot and the apple sauce was much better then. The crackling used to be better with a harder, more satisfying crunch to it. The one we had today was cold, some bits were burnt and only the top of the skin was crunchy while the rest of the fat below was still there in a hard gelatinous form.   The bun was also cold which didn't lend to the tepid pulled pork. In any case, the flavor was still there from back in the day. It was delicious nonetheless but I guess when you've made it big and have a storefront (or two, in this case), maybe you just don't work as hard like you did as a food truck only business.   The price was really reasonable considering the generous portion size.

_7dCw4NnCsVs9vnBG-eTSA.text: Descent food - descent prices. Not much sitting room - be careful the sandwiches are drippy. The chili jam is not spicy.

DOk1jW52mpFSykW7pb01cg.text: What's not to love? Delicious pulled pork with crackling and a choice of other filings and sauces. Absolutely banging hog roll!

DgNSrkpgp7xAZ3krsPFHfQ.text: Great concept with a roasted pig in the window for making sandwiches.  The choices are simple and tasty...very small and limited space if you want to eat there.  The sandwiches were very tasty we had one with an apple spread and one with haggis.

LU_pLuHbM1fPIkKrCwfL2g.text: Delicious, fast, and cheap!  I got the grunter with brown bread, haggis, and chilli jam. Great sweet and spicy flavor, and very filling!

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Not for vegetarians!
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

EIgEUJEj6XZT_1EmeBVpsg.text: Good roasted pork. Simple & straightforward. Not a lot of seasoning, although you have a choice of sage & onion or haggis stuffing & then a sauce. I opted for the sage & onion "stuffing". It's really more the consistency of creamed potatoes and they do a small swipe of it on the bread, then the pork and a squeeze of sauce. It's good. The "oink" portion is plenty unless you're starving! I had wished I had ordered the "piglet" size because it's a hearty sandwich. Definitely worth trying.

wvxoQw4XxjJ8mzP-DMjLUA.text: This is a great place for a delicious and quick sandwich pork sandwich. I ordered the 460g (large) pulled pork sandwich with brown bread, 'Homemade BBQ' sauce, and sage/onion stuffing. The pork was incredibly tender and the bread was super soft. In fact, I had to eat it still in the wrapper as it would have been impossible to pick it up otherwise. Delicious onion and sage stuffing (actually just a shmear). Tip - no inside seating was available as the place was SUPER busy when we arrived around lunch time. There is a decent amount of seating down the street at the square which, was only a short walk. So, grab a big pork sammich and don't forget a few napkins.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

MQ2ghzAWnhqHq-PpFZnLYQ.text: Delicious pulled pork sandwiches. We each had "The Oink"-- the medium-sized roll. It was enough for me, but the BF probably could've gotten the larger size. Make sure to ask for some of the crispy crackling with your sandwich. It's something yummy but simple and quick so you can continue sightseeing!

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

8S4Qc_4iPGIUEC-Ve3N2nQ.text: We visited both locations, the service is great. The sandwiches are huge, we're able to split the medium one easily. I seem to require more BBQ sauce than my husband and they add more to my side without question. It's tasty and the atmosphere is very cheery (if that's possible with the poor old pig sitting right there in the window). If you need a high-quality, quick meal, this is a good place for you to try.

7gIMWZxaQHmCsWg63mmAVQ.text: It was very good, but with southern US BBQ competing with this in my mind, it wasn't AMAZING. Maybe I played it too safe getting the Oink with haggis (tastes similar to stuffing) and apple for my sauce.

O-rUkUosMo0FC5qKkbZoxQ.text: A must when you're in Edinburgh! The pork is so juicy and flavorful. My hubby and I shared the Grunter and a bag of chips - it was plenty. Reasonably priced, too! We will be back.

OkuaVLVGEPsW7prYg1UD7g.text: I hiked Arthur's Seat early in the morning, and had worked up quite an appetite! I entered at the bottom end of The Royal Mile to walk up and find somewhere to grab some lunch.   Much to my pleasure, there on the left I saw a magnificently large roast pig in the window of a place called 'Oink'.   The name alone would have brought me in, but that pig in the window looked delicious.   The inside was cute, clean, and the staff was very friendly! But the food... holy hell the food! It is what dreams are made of! I quite literally will dream about those pulled pork sandwiches for the rest of my life!   I ordered mine without the haggis, and instead had the chutney jam; LIFE CHANGING! I don't think I even breathed while I ate that sandwich. And when it was gone I literally wanted to go order another one.   I did... but I waited until the next day! I could eat there everyday if I lived in Edinburgh.   The price was fantastic, and the food is amazing! Do yourself a favor and go Oink yourself the next time you're in Edinburgh.

G5m6qnFZFmJioRzuwTs2Vg.text: Great tasting pork sandwiches. Kinda reminds me of a porchetta sandwhich. The skin was a tad bit salty but it balance out well when eaten with everything else

JY7QR2DBF8QMCBuCmpPYIw.text: What I Ordered: The largest pulled pork sandwich Flavor: Pretty good.  Not the best pulled pork I've had, but they have some unique BBQ sauces.   Service: Standard.  Order, pay and eat. Atmosphere: Hole in the wall.  The most noticeable thing about the place is the half-carved pig in the window, which I actually found pretty cool and memorable. Price: Good for what you get. Location: In the heart of old town Edinburgh. Great location. Other Comments:  A good, fast option if you're looking for a break from typical pub food.

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

1CRdOYnX5NhLvYS8EKFJDg.text: "How big is the 'Oink' sandwich?"...  First off the mark I have to give a shout out to the staff who answered this question again and again with smiles on their faces while I was there. A valid question, in fairness, as the 'Oink' is the most popular choice here, but probably not great craic if you get asked it every five minutes.  Located on the very picturesque Victoria Street, Oink is the perfect place to go if you're looking for delicious food on the go. What you see is exactly what you get here, pulled pork sandwiches done really well. There's a very small seating area at the back but most people get their food to go. The service is excellent and turn-around time is probably only a couple of minutes. So how does it work? You choose your bread, size, sage and onion or haggis stuffing, sauce...and enjoy! I'd highly recommend grabbing a sandwich from here and rambling around Grassmarket, an afternoon well spent in my opinion!

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. &#34;Oink&#39; hog roast roll with sage and onion stuffing and mustard mayo!

Cyq3IExsDnaLOmffJJg8rQ.text: Great place to get a quick and cheap meal to go. Plus it's so tasty!  Get the meal of soda, chips, and pork sandwich for 6. We tried the pork sandwich with both applesauce and mayo/mustard. I think mayo/mustard is the way to go wince it's so creamy. The pork has tons of flavor, and the sandwich is a good portion.  It is a bit tricky to find if you come from the castle, because it's on the lower street level.

mrOZPxlvVjP9oooGDJQW8A.text: I had my first Oink yesterday at the new Canongate location. What a simple, wonderful treat it was. I had the pork on wheat roll with sage/onion, apple sauce and BBQ sauce while the boy had white roll, haggis and BBQ sauce. He said it was the best sandwich he'd ever had.

49MhbTDD8Cl0XWru2O3PPg.text: It's not what I expected. The meat didn't taste that good and the guy who served me smashed the roasted hog and the apple sauce into my roll as if he hates food like this. Will never come back!

m-amZ4HoXoEukwRn-Ez6Fw.text: Pro. This place is sooooo good, but get there early cause they run out of the cracklin' early! flickr.com/photos/theedi...

photos.caption: Photo of Oink - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

kUsIDF7BerkinrdslCSLhQ.text: Soft pork sandwiches in white bread is the only available order in this little themed lunch place. Well, you can choose what size sandwich and between white and even-whiter bread. This has all the building blocks of a truly mouthwatering, divine, porkalicious mouth extravaganza... But alas! the pork just isn't that good. The sour elements flat. The bread from plastic bags. I've had five star pork sandwiches, that I drive 45mins for. This is not it and you end up regretting not getting something else instead. Super nice service, though.

aFHP_gDVOBTKOlo56N8cpQ.text: Yummy! Simply put, you get a sandwich with shredded pork pulled literally off a pig while passerbys see this in the window. You get a crispy pig skin in the bun as well as apple spread or haggis. Easy to order, yummy to eat. Great drinks in the fridge too. No hours posted. The only place I've seen posted hours is right here on Yelp!

u87rgjPl16-dU5ybUz6z9Q.text: Brilliant idea. I understand why it closes at 3 because it's ran out of pig. The idea is that one whole hog is put in the window and you come and get a simple roll, there's only two options to have with it and that is apple sauce or stuffing and I was sad to see there was no butter (because that is the winning condiment when it comes to pork). Reasonably prices and a real novelty and a hearty lunch. Get there fast!

zxphzoXOHyqKSwa8gSs3Ng.text: Disappointing. The pork was very soft and there was plenty to eat but it lacked in taste. A little more salt in the mix please!

4PLZt8qn0RtyUCCmI0mBfw.text: One of my mottoes for finding a good restaurant is: if there's a carcass in the window it's good eats.  Well my friends, Oink has a giant, Hawaiian-style luau pig staring at you from their shop window and my motto has yet to prove me wrong.    We stumbled upon this place on our first trip to Edinburgh, wandering around in a daze of hunger with little money in our pockets.  I saw the pig in the window so we jumped in line, which was out the front door but moving quickly, for some assuredly good eats.    This is a takeaway, so not much room to sit down (if any) but we took ours down the street to Grassmarket and had a picnic there.  The food was super cheap, I can't remember the exact price but I want to say less than 6 for two sandwiches, and amazing.  We'll definitely be back.

SgfJE9WvA0UqtCFzu9Jt5w.text: Oink, oink! Having passed the piggy porn (full hog roast) in the window many times, throwing a few wistful glances its way, I thought it was out of bounds for GF me. Pretty simple, hog roast, stuffing or haggis, sauces (including apple and chilli) in a white or brown roll and comes in three portion sizes. I decided to sample some hog roast, in a tub so no roll or stuffing and the girls in store thought it might be GF but weren't totally sure. I asked for a Oink portion (3.60 for an Atkins diet dream portion of pig) and it was delish! No poisoning or GF after effects so I'll definitely return to Oink for a portion of fab hog roast :-)

lzLo9Uc-xX5c0x9hWVwPdA.text: Here in Edinburgh on vacation and was checking out the Yelp Reviews.  Thank you all for your Oink recommendation.  Juicy and wonderful with the Spicy Cheese and Apple Sauce.  It dripped down my jacket but I didn't care.  Will go again tomorrow.  Thank you Yelpers.

j0XcCrM-lwi2ZxemWnpiFw.text: Yummy place! I love shredded pork and adding apple sauce to it was a great touch!!! Found this place just by walking by!

L5u7bvvxuCvsQ50aSgD0lw.text: The first time I walked past this place I had to do a double take because of the half mauled pig in the window. Poor guy. But I was intrigued and thought I must try it!   There is not much else you can do to explain OINK. There is a dead pig in the window and they carve it up for sandwiches. Its as easy as that. Its probably for the more carnivorous amongst us, some people may be put off by Babe in the window. But it is delicious! I like mine with a little apple sauce. I leave the crackling though, that grosses me out a bit too much. The pigs are reared on the owners farm, so its good quality meet too.  Its maybe quite gimmicky, but worth a try.

FmGaRftrjg_3geQhSKom5Q.text: If you can eat pork then I cannot recommend this place enough- just thinking about it makes me drool. It serves one thing and one thing only: hog roast.  The meat is always cooked to perfection- melt in your mouth and the crackling has always been satisfying! The buns are fresh and even though there is not a huge variety in additional fillings (the apple sauce and sage and onion combo are delicious) they do them very well. Prices are not the cheapest but trust me- you will want more.  It's a tiny shop with one table and some stools so be prepared to take away. Even though the hog roast comes in buns it tends to get quite messy as they are quite generous with portions. Also the crackling goes early. What is most striking about this small modern food shop is the actual carcass of the pig is a window display. I suppose this is the best kind of advertisement. It also is quite amusing when people watching the reactions it gets- I am sure the staff here are used to the snapping of photos.   I love this funky little shop and the food is delicious. Your vegetarian friends might be in for a bit of a  shock though.

uhQcbzG2oUC8mOBQgeqqNw.text: My sister and I visited this fine city in May and we passed Oink and smelled the ever so yummy pork aroma and marched on in.  I had told her that we need to eat haggis at some point because someone back home will ask and we cant wimp out and say no.  The very nice young man at the counter told us our sandwich options and when the dressings included haggis I asked him if it was good ( as if Id know the difference!) and he said " yes, its homemade by my Aunt".  Well who can say no to good home cooking?  It was actually good and I had that, the sage and onion and the applesauce on my big oink sandwich and was very happy with the entire experience as well as being able to scratch "eating haggis" off my list of things to do. Edinburgh in general was a wonderful place to visit and I wish we had had a few more days, but oh well, guess we'll have to go back!

ydE7JZNIKPoNhKKcWSNdJw.text: Awesome, awesome. True Farm to market - the owner is the farmer and the pigs are his pigs. The meat is fresh and tasty - get it with the haggis, chili sauce and apple sauce. Ask for extra sauce. Great flavor, quick service, and super affordable for lunch. One of the best lunches I had in Scotland.

DxCVxpZp0B3ICU1QUNfUzA.text: I don't know how best to describe this place...... The only thing I can say is that I feel sad that I will never taste a better sandwich EVER!!!

4vh5LZsMDNJQvmEnw_hg-Q.text: Cash only! Craving this while I'm writing this review... Great place to grab a yummy and filling takeaway sandwich! I tried the wheat roll with haggis and chili cheese, a combination I definitely recommend! Wish I came back more than once- highly recommend!!

5spe4sQpCgXgmarilW3SSA.text: A really original little lunch spot just up from Grassmarket, Oink was a favourite of mine during long stints at the National Library. With a whole hog roasting in the window, it reminds me of one of those Medieval feasts, eating whole animals while quaffing wine. Well there was less quaffing to be done here but the food is exactly as mouth watering as Robin Hood led me to believe as a child.  The pig is slow cooked, so is really tender and flavoursome. And thankfully it is nice and juicy as well, not dried out like pork in so many other places. You don't really have much of a choice if you want food here, you're going to get food so lucky it's really good. You do have a choice with the extras though, you can add a selection of the following: - sage and onion stuffing - pork crackling - apple sauce - chilli sauce  The rolls are about 4 quid, and whilst a bit more expensive than a sarnie from other cafes, are absolutely amazing. They are also ridiculously filling as well, so you don't have that feeling half an hour after you walk out where you're hungry again. If you want excellent, slightly original food then look no further.

IEN2yimNFf6u0SmhClFaKA.text: I like pork a lot, so I guess it makes sense that I'd like A LOT of pork.  Situated on Victoria St. right off of the grassmarket, Oink is an honest, unassuming eatery specializing in pulled-pork sandwiches.  Did I say specializing?  Is there a word for "it's the only thing on the menu"? There isn't?  Well alright then.  If you do not like pork: first of all, what the hell man?  Second of all, this isn't the place for you.  In fact, you probably should have been warned off by the roast pig carcass in the window.  Yes, they have one of those.  You walk up to the counter in what is a rather small looking space, with seating for about 5-6 people.  There you can order one of three things.... ALL OF THEM ARE A PULLED PORK SANDWICH!  Just differing sizes of such.  You have the choice of the roll (white or brown), the choice of topping (haggis or sage and onion stuffing or both) and the choice of relish (apple or chili).  This may seem like a difficult decision, but let me assure you: THERE ARE NO WRONG ANSWERS.  Any and every combination will be no more or less mouth-watering and delicious as any other.    The person working there (always nice) will then proceed to scrape a generous portion of pig (as in directly from the pig) onto your roll, wrap it some plastic and deliver it to your trembling hands.  This will set you back between 3 and 5 quid, depending on the size.  Now there's not a huge amount of seating, so if you go on a weekend, you may find it difficult to find a place to sit.  This is ok, however, because there are no end to the benches down on Grassmarket.  Plus, several of them have a view of that castle-y thingamajig everybody seems to rave about.  **Hint, if you leave make sure to grab a fork and a napkin (pulled pork has a tendency to fall out of things...)  I hope I have conveyed (without actually saying so) that Oink is awesome and you should never eat anywhere else and you should give me all of your money.  But in case I haven't made that clear... GO TO OINK, you won't regret it.  I accept most major credit cards.

Rks6KN0NOzBb1cuNQ9Ylfg.text: Just had an oink (a sandwhich) this afternoon. The place keeps the menu simple with only a few items to choose from but those few items sure do taste good. Pick a roll, pick a sauce, put some hog on there and your out the door in under 2 minutes! Definitely try it out!

mkrp74RKSVZeN_KNblZguQ.text: As I was wandering the streets of Edinburgh in search of a quick lunch near the castle, I came across Oink. First off, what a great name. Seriously, Oink? Add to that the fact that the storefront is accented with a flamboyant shade of hot pink, and you've caught my attention from afar. But wait, it gets better. As I approached the storefront, I was greeted by the sight of a whole-roasted pig, head and all, staring back at me through the window. Sure, I loved Babe just as much as the next child, but any time a roasted animal is presented to me, any affectionate childhood memories I may have had are pushed to the backburner.  Since I'm Chinese, I am perfectly comfortable with and used to seeing animals cooked whole, head and all. Suckling pigs, steamed fish, and roasted chickens are all commonly prepared and served with their heads still on, so seeing a cooked animal head isn't particularly shocking. But for some reason, many Americans get freaked out or disgusted by seeing animal heads. Does the fact that the animal's head is still on somehow make the food seem more alive or less suitable for consumption? I don't know, it just seems so irrational to me when someone is grossed out by seeing a cooked chicken head but is perfectly content with eating chicken wings and drumsticks from the KFC down the street. They all come from the same animal, so what's the big deal? Besides, when was the last time you had a whole-roasted animal that wasn't delicious? Right, never.  Okay, moving on to the actual food. Well, if you couldn't tell by the name of the store or the fact that there's a roasted pig sitting in front of the window, Oink specializes in hog roasts. There's one thing and one thing only on their menu: pulled pork sandwiches. The only choices you have are the size of the sandwich and the type of roll, spread, and relish. Since I'm a fatass and of the belief that there is a positive correlation between the amount of meat on a sandwich and said sandwich's tastiness, I went with the "Grunter," which has more than eight ounces of pork stuffed inside of a soft roll. Topped with haggis and both the apple and chili relishes and crowned with a piece of crispy pork crackling, this was a behemoth of a sandwich and quite a sight to behold. Not greasy in the slightest and with all of the subcutaneous fat rendered, the pork crackling was superb, reminiscent of the crisp skin that you would get with a Chinese suckling pig. The sandwich, overflowing with so much meat that you can't even see the bottom bun in the pictures, was exactly what you would expect more than half a pound of pork stuffed inside of a roll to taste like: insanely delicious and fatty. The meat was actually a bit on the dry side, but that's where the haggis, apple relish, and chili relish came into play, as they all helped to add a bit of moisture to the sandwich without completely soaking the bun.  Ten minutes and countless napkins later, I sat back in my seat with an immense feeling of satisfaction. I'm no pulled pork connoisseur, but this was most certainly a terrific rendition of the sandwich, so much so in fact that I hopped back on line to get another sandwich for my dinner on the train ride home that evening. 4.60 for a sandwich of this size is an extremely fair deal, and I walked away perfectly sated and content. If I should ever find myself back in Edinburgh sometime in the future, Oink would definitely be near the top of my list of places to visit.
